Example

Suppose we consider the square wave



Here \(f(t)\) has finite discontinuities at \(-\pi\), \(0\) and \(\pi\). The Fourier series of \(f(t)\) is \[ \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{2}{\pi} \left( \sin t + \dfrac{1}{3} \sin 3t + \dfrac{1}{5} \sin 5t + \dots \right) .\] At \(t = \dfrac{\pi}{2}\), for example, where \(f(t)\) is continuous the square wave converges to \( f \left( \dfrac{\pi}{2}\right) = 1\). On the other hand at \(t = \pi\) the Fourier series clearly has the value \( \dfrac{1}{2}\) (since all the sine terms are zero here). This value \( \dfrac{1}{2} \) agrees with the average of the two limiting values of \(f(t)\) at \(t = \dfrac{\pi}{2} : \dfrac{1}{2} (1+0) = \dfrac{1}{2} \). If we actually put \(t = \dfrac{\pi}{2}\) in the Fourier series we obtain \[ \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{2}{\pi} \left( \sin \left( \dfrac{\pi}{2} \right) + \dfrac{1}{3} \sin \left( \dfrac{3\pi}{2} \right) + \dfrac{1}{5} \sin \left( \dfrac{5\pi}{2} \right) + \dots \right) \] \[ = \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{2}{\pi} \left( 1 - \dfrac{1}{3} + \dfrac{1}{5} - \dfrac{1}{7} + \dots \right) \] Since the series converges, as we have seen, to \(f \left( \dfrac{\pi}{2} \right) = 1\), we obtain the interesting result \[ \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{2}{\pi} \left( 1 - \dfrac{1}{3} + \dfrac{1}{5} - \dfrac{1}{7} + \dots \right) = 1 \] or \[ 1 - \dfrac{1}{3} + \dfrac{1}{5} - \dfrac{1}{7} + \dots = \dfrac{\pi}{4} \]
